name: Random Variable
description:
A random variable (RV) is a function $X$ that maps the sample space to the real numbers. That is to say, $X(\omega): \Omega \mapsto \mathbb{R}$.

We have events $\omega\in\Omega$ and random variables assign "values" to these events. Before performing the experiment, we clearly do not know the results of our experiment (which event $\omega$ actually happens) so we don't know the value of $X(\omega)$. This is what we call randomness.

Any function $X:\Omega\mapsto\mathbb{R}^d$ is called a $\mathbb{R}^d$-valued random variable. If there exists an $x\in\mathbb{R}^d$ such that $X(\omega)=x$ for all $\omega\in\Omega$, then $X$ is called deterministic (often used in a pseudo-random context). If $X$ is not deterministic, then it is called truly random.
